drupalNodeEvent.title: In-person Event | States, Citizenship, and Welfare in India and China

field_speakers.processed:
Deborah Davis, Professor Emerita of Sociology, Yale University

Qin Gao, Professor of Social Policy and Social Work, Columbia university

Andaleeb Rahman, Research Associate, Tata-Cornell Institute, Department of Global Development, Cornell University

Sanjay Ruparelia, Associate Professor, Jarislowsky Democracy Chair, Toronto Metropolitan University

field_organizers.processed: India China Institute at The New School

drupalNodeEvent.field_event_venue: Starr Foundation Hall (UL102), 63 Fifth Ave New York,  NY  10003

field_description.processed: In China, recent reforms have aimed at expanding social security coverage, improving healthcare, and addressing rural-urban disparities. India has launched several ambitious welfare schemes aimed at poverty alleviation, healthcare, food security, and right to work programs. By virtue of population size, these programs are among the largest social policy initiatives in the world. But they are also insightful examples of welfare provision based less on rights-based entitlements and more on achieving state goals of development, social stability, political loyalty, and promotion of more exclusive conceptions of citizenship. This panel explores changing welfare policies and politics in China and India, and their roles in anchoring new forms of authoritarian or illiberal governance.
